data.text: Power Banks: What Should I Buy?

Power bank question for ya. I need to replace a power bank that had an unfortunate interaction with water and figured it a good time to see what is out there. So I am wondering what you all prefer? I’m charging Wahoo Elemnt Roam, GoPro, DJI Mini 2, and iPhone over an average three-four nights. TIA
Usually Anker models are quite reliable. Looks like you need a fairly big one.
data.author: Pierre Moreels

data.text: 2x10,000mah anker will do. Not cheap but worth it IMO. I’d buy 2x10,000 rather than 1x20,000 from a redundancy perspective. If one gets wet or damaged, you’ll have another.
data.author: Keat Brigham

data.text: Actually, having read what you’re hoping to keep running, I’d be looking at a Dynamo hub charging a buffer battery as you’ll have to carry more than 20,000mah of capacity to keep all that running. Especially the GoPro.
data.author: Keat Brigham

data.text: Anything Anker. I’ve got a couple of their models that are pushing 5+ years old and they haven’t skipped a beat
data.author: Jeff Clemons

data.text: Anker powercore III elite :) a bit expensive but 60W charging is amazingly fast!
data.author: Justus Baer

data.text: If you want to keep all that charged 20k power bank and a dyno plus a 21w or larger solar array. Anker makes great batteries and solar panels
data.author: Tom Cavan

data.text: Do I say it? Anker 20K. They have a quick charge plug too.
data.author: Lee Hollenbeck

data.text: There are also bike light powerbanks. Instead of having a PB and a bike light, you can have one that functions as both.
data.author: Brian Graves

data.text: 🤔 smart
data.author: Kimberly Much

data.text: look for something that has quick charge 3.0 or above. i found one for under forty bucks, and pair it with another 10,000mAh one to compare the differences. we'll see if short stops at coffee shops will keep which one charged the most. i was always the person the carry a solar panel, but this trip, I'm ditching the headache and using that weight saved to carry another power pack. i mean I'm stopping to recharge my body anyways, might as well do the batteries too. that said, i think i might miss the independence
data.author: Brent Joly

data.text: If you are using a dynamo, some of the larger and faster charging power banks won’t take a charge well. The dynamo does not put out a sufficiently consistent voltage.
data.author: Brian Butler

data.text: best in the market right here to my knowledge, if theres a better one show me and explain
data.author: Christian Ramos

data.text: used it for my gopros, mini 2, galaxy s20, lights, garmin, everything
data.author: Christian Ramos

data.text: nitecore are waterproof and submersible. I just bought one from jefevelo and it's pretty awesome but can't say I have put it to the test yet. I trust its claims though and mounted right in between the aerobars
data.author: Zeno Molteni

data.text: this is the one I got, they also have a 10mAh and 5mAh, the 20mAh is the only one that has USB-C in (and out), the other two have micro USB in
data.author: Zeno Molteni

data.text: 🤔
data.author: Kimberly Much

data.text: Yes, I have seen them. They are lighter but not waterproof. Personally, I'd go with the waterproof option
data.author: Zeno Molteni

data.text:
Not trying to hijack this, but this is also something I'm concerned about. Thinking of buying two of these. For the same devices mentioned in this post. Would it suffice? I don't want to spend the money on a Dynamo (admittedly haven't looked into it enough, but it looks like $400-500 for a whole thing?). https://www.walmart.com/ip/PowerCore-Select-20000-Power-Bank-Dual-Port-Portable-Phone-Charger/434391010?wmlspartner=wlpa&selectedSellerId=0&wl13=3795&adid=22222222278434391010_117755028669_12420145346&wmlspartner=wmtlabs&wl0=&wl1=g&wl2=m&wl3=501107745824&wl4=pla-293946777986&wl5=1023191&wl6=&wl7=&wl8=&wl9=pla&wl10=8175035&wl11=local&wl12=434391010&wl13=3795&veh=sem_LIA&gclid=EAIaIQobChMI5-S2gPKE9wIVCsDICh2b0AH5EAQYAiABEgJPffD_BwE&gclsrc=aw.ds

data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: Nitecore
data.author: Garrett Hudson

data.text: Anker I have a 26000 and have never emptied it.
data.author: Matt Dunmore

data.text: same
data.author: Eric Taylor

data.text: Can find decent battery banks at Walmart in the discount section pretty regularly.
data.author: Ben Bierdeman

data.text: Pedal Cell
data.author: Brad Pierro

data.text: Nitecore 10k mah is the lightest and smallest. Love it. Prob need two.
data.author: Darrin Commerford

data.text: Goal Zero Venture 75 is pretty solid. 20OZ 19200mAh. I own this one and the 70(Older Version) and they have been flawless.
data.author: Thomas Ray

data.text: Anker 20000 mAh 👍can’t fault it.
data.author: Andy Wright

data.text: I'm looking also bought this one in pic and it's junk, takes 10hrs to charge me phone.
data.author: Peter Cartier

data.text: good to know thx
data.author: Kimberly Much

data.text: Pedalcell and an Ankor battery for backup. But I'll probably never need it.
data.author: Jeff Emrich

data.text: I Use Pedalcell, flipping awesome. I also have a front light that can charge and be used simultaneously, that just so happens to also be a power bank.
data.author: Julian Clarke

data.text: If I'm out for 2 or more nights I carry 2 powerbanks and a mains charger. I can use the powerbanks on the move and the mains charger in cafes and sleepovers. I recharched my phone and main powerbank in a 24hr McDonald's while having breakfast once on 1000km audax. Phone has quick charge, so does my back up front light. You could try a solar powered charger for longer journeys that I've seen and a good investment is dynamo lights, again not something I've tried but worth looking into.
data.author: Craig Boyde

data.text:
One of these with 18650 batteries recovered from old laptops should easily cover you for the whole 4 days without needing topping up https://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/265011286900?hash=item3db3e75374:g:KFcAAOSw4uhf~W6Y
Detachable DIY 16x18650 Battery Case LCD Display Power Bank Shell Charger Box | eBay

data.author: Robert Draycott
